bibl.title: Letter from Lawrence Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 19, 1900

div1.p: Lawrence Reed describes his quarters and asks his mother to send him reading material. He sends cash to his sister, Blossom, and warns her to be careful when she is out in public.

div1.head: Letter from Lawrence Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 19, 1900
div1.p:
I wrote to
you yesterday, so imagine
this will be a little surprise
for you- Your letter of the
12th reached me this morning
and I will answer it now
as you asked a few questions
I want to answer at once.
When I first wrote you
for a few pillows & rugs -- etc
I thought you might
have a few at home you
would like to sell -- but
then when I got this letter
this morning I recalled that
every thing is packed & stored
away, so never mind if I decide
to get any thing I can order
them in New York and they can
be put on the Transport
there & will save expense -- of express from Wash
The only thing I really should
like for you to do is to
send me three or four good
books a month -- say two at
a time and tell me the price
and I will always pay for
them-

I have a cot with a mattress
on it and an army blanket over
it & I call it a divan, it
is without pillows but it answers
all purposes- I thought that
I would make a divan & get two
or three pillows & a cover for it
but have given up the idea, now
I have a little center table I made
myself its about 3 feet sq.
& I have another army blanket
over it with a little center
piece Mrs Hoyt present me
with so for the present it
will do- I have a nice roll
top desk & revolving chair --
and a nice morris chair by
my center table -- a wash
stand made here & covered
with oil cloth -- a place
to hang my clothes covered with
pretty blue cloth -- a government
bunk -- two boxes (chests) both
covered with Army blankets and
a trunk -- so I am more
than comfortable-

By the way I will order the
gloves from Allien-

So all you allhave to do is to
select the books now & then
for me- I have just finished
“Soldiers of Fortune” & thought
it was quite good.

Dearest please dont little let
Blossom go in the peanut gallery.
Its not the place for her-
I have been there too often and
I know what I am talking
about. 50¢ or 75¢ will
get her a seat in the balcony
& thats the place for her. I
enclose two dollars -- give it
to her with my best love & tell
her if she will stop going there
Darboy will promise her several
treas a month-

closer.salute:
With dearest
love your aff son
